li.p:
Cumulative SAT scores are normally distribute with mean 1100 and standard deviation 200. Use this information to sketch a diagram and answer each of the questions below.
Approximately what percent of SAT scores are at or between 700 and 1500?
What percent of SAT scores are less than or equal to 1500? What percent of the scores of 1500 or more?
The scores of 68% of test takers are expected to be at or between what two values?
What percent of SAT scores are at or between 1100 and 1300?
The top 2.5% of the students will have a score greater than or equal to what value?
What is the probability that a randomly selected student has an SAT score of 1300 or greater?
What percent of SAT scores are 500 or less?
What is the probability that a randomly selected student has an SAT score at or between 900 and 1500?
What is the probability that a randomly selected student has an SAT score at or between 1300 and 1700?

Suppose 460 high school seniors in a particular school district took the SAT exam.
Approximately how many of the seniors in the district are expected to earn scores at or between 900 and 1500?
Approximately how many of these students are expected to earn scores of 1300 or greater?
Approximately 320 of the students are expected to earn a minimum score of what value?
Approximately how many of the students are expected to earn scores or 1700 or higher?
Approximately how many of the students are expected to earn scores at or between 700 and 1300?

ol.li: Suppose 60\% of voters favor candidate A over candidate B. Determine the standard deviation and 95\% confidence interval for a polling sample of 1000 individuals.

li.p:
Suppose 52\% of voters favor candidate A over candidate B.
Determine the standard deviation and 95\% confidence interval for a polling sample of 1000 individuals.
Find the probability that the poll will predict a majority in favor of candidate B.
Explain why the size of the actual voting population does not need to be given in this problem.
